title: Apostolo, la recensione dell'horror Netflix
body:
Apostolo, la recensione dell’horror Netflix

Apostolo (Apostle) è un horror del 2018 diretto da Gareth Evans, e distribuito dal servizio di streaming Netflix. Questa è la nostra recensione.

Prodotto da XYZ Films e Severn Screen, l’horror Apostolo è stato diretto da Gareth Evans, regista di film di successo come The Raid e V/H/S 2. Nel cast spazio per Dan Stevens, Paul Higgins, Michael Sheen e Lucy Boynton.

Ambientato in un periodo…

View On WordPress

summary: 'Apostle' Ending Explained: Gareth Evans Break Down His Netflix Movie's Freaky Finale
title: 'Apostle' Ending Explained: Gareth Evans Break Down His Netflix Movie's Freaky Finale
excerpt: 'Apostle' director Gareth Evans breaks down the freaky final moments of his new Netflix horror film starring Dan Stevens as a man taking on a killer cult.

summary: “Apostle” Analysis and Review - Look, there's a LOT of crazy we need to show you here and we only have a couple hours (B+,...
title: “Apostle” Analysis and Review - Look, there's a LOT of crazy we need to show you here and we only have a couple hours (B+, Spoilers)
body:
Gareth Evans does not want to tell you a story with Apostle. Gareth Evans wants to SHOW you a story with Apostle. He wants you to feel the story, not comprehend every little part of it. He isn’t interested in explaining all the details of the plot because exposition is boring, and it’s not important anyway. This is a tale told in the broad strokes of an allegory, not in the minute background details of a realistic character drama.

For Evans, all we need to know about our cast of characters are the basics. For instance, our hero Thomas is a former man of God who has lost everything, including his faith. He has nothing left in this life to care about except for his sister, Jennifer, who was there for him when no one else was. We don’t learn more than that about their relationship or actually see them together for more than a minute, but again, those are just a couple of the many unimportant, piddling details that are missing here.

Ok, maybe I’m being a bit unfair to Evans about the narrative issues. Maybe the film just had way too much story to tell and he was forced to edit out 90% of the exposition. You can generally glean what may have happened in the past to these characters with what you’re given, but still, it’s a major problem of the film. Thankfully it’s the only major one, because the rest of this movie is gorgeous, dramatic, and thrilling.

Apostle is only part bloody horror movie, really. Mostly it’s a historical fairy tale about the corruption of religion when mixed with greed and politics. It’s not as biting a social commentary as The Devils was or one of the many other Brit/European horror films of the 60’s and 70’s that it pays tribute to, but it’s a good homage to them and manages to uniquely set itself apart.

The three leaders of the story’s setting, the island of Erisden (which literally means “lair of discord”), are representations of corrupt leadership, the irony being of course that they have run away from society to live in a supposed Utopia of their own design. Malcolm is a charismatic leader who turns Erisden into a religious cult and fully believes in his Chosen status. He thinks of himself as a moral and loving leader, though he is easy to condone evil deeds done for the good of community. Quinn is the man behind the scenes who does all the dirty work of keeping the followers in line and feeding those who don’t to the “machine” that keeps Erisden running. He is jealous, ambitious, possessive of his daughter, and twisted with violence and a desire for power. Frank is an ordinary man who simply wants to live and raise his family happily in Erisden. He serves as the silently consenting dogsbody of the other two.

The central figure of their religion is She, who is both a metaphor and a literal supernatural being of unknown origin. She represents the land that they live off of and if “the Land and the King are one” as they so often are in allegories, then She has become a Dark Crone version of Mother Nature. Evil men have enslaved her and fed her poison and she gives them the same in return, but of course they don’t understand why. There’s some kind of servant referred to as The Grinder in the credits, but all we learn about him is that he’s scary, bloody, and that he grinds things to feed She.

In this particular brand of horror film, young women are generally wise and kind and represent the fruitful life and purity of soul that men either aspire to or lust after. They are loved and protected by the male protagonists and abused and threatened by the antagonists. So it goes with Andrea and Ffion. Both are full of goodness and love, but neither shy away from their sexuality (fertility is an important theme of Apostle, and how it’s denied or destroyed by mankind’s failings).

Andrea is a woman of both faith and science and she keeps their community going in many ways, but she’s never listened to by her father or the other leaders. When Thomas comes to Erisden in search of his ransomed sister, he of course notices Andrea right away and is drawn to her, but his troubled soul prevents them from fully connecting.

Meanwhile Ffion is a simple, honest girl in love with the only innocent male in the story, Jeremy. The purity of their dream to build a home and raise a family is crushed by her father Quinn, who hasn’t seen a toxic masculine trope he didn’t love. His relationship with Ffion is abusive and creepy as Evans can make it without openly showing incest. Predictably, it all ends in tears.

The performances are grand and dramatic, which is typical of the theatrical nature of old school Brit Horror. Dan Stevens, in Full Velvety Posh Voice Mode, does his usual competent job of carrying the film on his shoulders as Thomas. He happily indulges himself in ACTING while pulling it back just far enough to keep his character real enough to invest in. Michael Sheen’s performance as Malcolm is surprisingly subdued and sympathetic. Mark Lewis Jones gives a great melodramatic turn as Quinn and is the big surprise of the film for me. Lucy Boynton as Andrea is all pale grace and gorgeousness but you can still see the strength in her character. Sharon Morgan’s scene-stealing performance as She will probably go unappreciated, but her terrifying mysteriousness pulls the whole film together.

At the end of Apostle, you probably won’t really know what all just happened. There’s blood and fire and vines and things, but not a lot of explanation. Thomas is a dead man who has been brought back to life, sort of, but his future and the island’s is uncertain. A sequel with Dan Stevens as a supernatural semi-villain figure would be kinda cool to see, I admit, but mostly because I just love watching him in crazy roles. It’s a fairly complete and neat little tale, all in all, just not a fully realized one.
body_abstract: Gareth Evans does not want to tell you a story with Apostle. Gareth Evans wants to SHOW you a story with Apostle. He wants you to feel the story, not comprehend every little part of it. He isn’t interested in explaining all the details of the plot because exposition is boring, and it’s not important anyway. This is a tale told in the broad strokes of an allegory, not in the minute background details of a realistic character drama.

Michael Sheen’s performance as Malcolm is surprisingly subdued and sympathetic. Mark Lewis Jones gives a great melodramatic turn as Quinn and is the big surprise of the film for me. Lucy Boynton as Andrea is all pale grace and gorgeousness but you can still see the strength in her character. Sharon Morgan’s scene-stealing performance as She will probably go unappreciated, but her terrifying mysteriousness pulls the whole film together.

At the end of Apostle, you probably won’t really know what all just happened. There’s blood and fire and vines and things, but not a lot of explanation. Thomas is a dead man who has been brought back to life, sort of, but his future and the island’s is uncertain. A sequel with Dan Stevens as a supernatural semi-villain figure would be kinda cool to see, I admit, but mostly because I just love watching him in crazy roles. It’s a fairly complete and neat little tale, all in all, just not a fully realized one.

summary: Michael Sheen Talks Getting Inside a Cult Leader’s Head
title: Michael Sheen Talks Getting Inside a Cult Leader’s Head
excerpt: The journeyman actor opens up about his new Netflix cult thriller ‘Apostle’ and his upcoming sci-fi opus, the adaptation of Neil Gaiman’s ‘Good Omens.’

summary: 4YE Reviews: Netflix's Apostle Is Tense But Underdeveloped
title: 4YE Reviews: Netflix's Apostle Is Tense But Underdeveloped
body:
4YE Reviews: Netflix’s Apostle Is Tense But Underdeveloped

Credit: Netflix

Horror films are permeating the market and have for some time. Seeing as it is October, it’s no surprise that Netflix saved Gareth Evans’ newest film Apostle for the spooky season. The film has no shortness of gore, blood, and sinister dealings. Beyond the casting, Apostlehas nothing new to give the genre. In fact, Evans seems to employ all the typical tropes of horror films,…

trail.content:
4YE Reviews: Netflix’s Apostle Is Tense But Underdeveloped

External image
External image

Credit: Netflix

Horror films are permeating the market and have for some time. Seeing as it is October, it’s no surprise that Netflix saved Gareth Evans’ newest film Apostle for the spooky season. The film has no shortness of gore, blood, and sinister dealings. Beyond the casting, Apostlehas nothing new to give the genre. In fact, Evans seems to employ all the typical tropes of horror films,…

View On WordPress

summary: Apostoł - Po napisach | z pasją o filmach
title: Apostoł - Po napisach | z pasją o filmach
excerpt: Recenzja filmu "Apostoł" 2018), reż. Gareth Evans. Dan Stevens, Kristine Froseth, Michael Sheen, Bill Milner, Mark Lewis Jones
description:
Gareth Evans tak szybko zawiązuje wydarzenia w swoim filmie “Apostoł”, że miałem wrażenie, iż niechybnie czeka nas festiwal atrakcji niczym w jego serii “The Raid”. Myliłem się, bo “Apostoł” to głównie klimat. Klimat, który rzadko (choć siarczyście) daje dojść do głosu wspomnianej akcji.  

Reżyser tym razem uprawia szeroko rozumiany thriller pożeniony z kinem grozy, który postanowił wykończyć kilkoma bezlitosnymi aktami.   


“Apostoł” już hula na Netflix. Ode mnie dostaje 7-. Recenzja na blogu.

blog.name: michaelsheen
blog.title: michaelsheen
blog.description:
Brittany. 22.
Stannis Baratheon loyalist. 
Masters of Sex, Mad Men, A Song of Ice and Fire, and a shitload of other tv shows, movies, video games, history and the occasional old man. 
Michael Sheen is the supreme bae. 
Christoph Waltz and John Slattery get an honorable mention. 
Bobby Kennedy deserved better.
